segments.text: If you've got a black officer out here and he gets involved in a scuffle with somebody and his matchstick slips and hits him across the forehead and they bleed like a stuffed pig, NAACP will not take or pursue a complaint of police brutality against a black officer.
period.

If it was a white officer involved in the same action, the NAACP and their representatives would scream to high heaven, build a corps, provide demonstration marches and the whole bit, trying to get this officer not only fired,
But put my penitentiary.
Your ACLU, American Civil Liberties Union, operates on the same theory that if a person's civil rights are violated, they will go to any extreme to guarantee that that person's
civil rights and all of society's civil rights be guaranteed or punishment or retribution for a violation of them.
But if it involves a policeman, they won't take a case defending a policeman or trying to improve his civil rights or guarantee that he even has a civil right.
Reason being that they want issues that involve publicity.
They want the publicity so that they can get the financial donations to perpetuate the ACLU.
The cases involving the policemen don't generate any favorable publicity.
Situations like that tend to make you hesitate doing your job.
It gives you the attitude that people are going to get what they're doing to pay for it.
You get cynical as hell.
In the past, a policeman would be, as the understanding goes, involved in police action, take police
action and solve a case or put an end to a disturbance at the scene.
Now he writes a piece of paper and does nothing.
A similar train of thought there.
What kind of impact did affirmative action programs have for Fort Worth and the police department?
Quite a bit.
In hiring, the police department don't hire its people.
All the city employees go through the personnel office.
the city personnel office, and then are sent to where a vacancy exists.
So every applicant has been pre-screened and pre-tested by the personnel office before you ever see them on the final job site or final employer or interview or whatever you want to call it.
They send you a list of names, and you make your own appointments for them.
You cannot accept or reject any of the applicants.
You can tell the personnel office what you want, and they will notify you.
The personnel office is not interested at all in who you hire, but they want to know
a justifiable legal reason for everyone you turn down.
And it better fit within the affirmative action rules.
You can't say you're hiring this one because this one has more experience or this one will be a better employee.
They want the reason for turning them down.
Then give them down who you hire.
Do you think it affects the effectiveness of the police department in the long run?
If it affects the quality of your personnel, sure it does.
And it does affect the quality of your personnel because instead of hiring ten people out here that are broad, well-rounded, physical, capable,

people you hire three that are minorities simply because they are minorities and they fit in the category uh you give them special grades on all of their interviews so it's going to affect your overall effectiveness and this letter you mentioned uh
You didn't give me a year, but I'm assuming it was late 60s, early 70s.
You had an officer killed by a young black sniper.
How does something like this affect the interactions you had with blacks on the street, or does it?
It affected them real strong at that time.
in the period of time between the incident when it occurred and the later apprehension of the sniper, I forget what the time was, a month, six weeks, we said what time, the police officers naturally

take their own protection first and at the expense of appearance what i'm getting at is at say a traffic stop where you stop somebody running stop sign and you walk up to the car and ask to see if i have a license in preparation for writing them a ticket to run the stop sign at that time they'd walk up to the car carrying a loaded cop shotgun
They wouldn't walk up with a pencil in their hand and a ticket book in the other.
They'd walk up asking the driver's license with a shotgun in their hand.
Yeah, it affects you, how you feel, how you act, because you don't know who you're talking to.
What do you think the reaction is?
Well, this is a hypothetical question.
What kind of reaction do you think it would have been if instead of a black guy it had been a drugged out hippie?
Would that have changed the way the force reacted?
At that time, there was no such thing as a drugged out hippie.
That came later.
It was prior to the drug culture.
Okay, I'm trying to aim that question.
If it had just been a, oh, okay.
What I'm trying to get at is if it had been a white or an Asian, if it had been somebody else, would that have affected the same way?
I mean, with tension, with anything like that, do tensions rise regardless of who it is?
I mean, look, to give you an example,
Several years later, this would be approximately 10 years ago.
It would be about 76, I imagine.
We had an incident on the west side where we had a black walking down the street shooting a pistol.
Broad daylight.
Two cars were sent, both of them one-man cars.
One officer pulled up.
He knew the Black.
He was a middle case.
He knew him.
He had talked with him before.
Instead of waiting for his backup unit to get there, he called for him to come over and sit in the car.
The man did.
What happened in that car, I don't know.
Nobody ever knows for sure, but we're guessing.
The pistol
The black was carrying mud off and killed the policeman.
He was white.
He was a policeman with about 28 years experience.
When the other car got there, which was less than two or three blocks away at the time,
The black jumped out of the car and ran to the other car, hollering for help, because this officer had been shot.
There was no department-wide hard feelings toward blacks incident.
There was no big public sentiment for or against.
It was a policeman that had, for some reason,
had violated departmental policy in that he hadn't waited for it back up yet to get there with him.
The black was a middle case.
Been in and out of the hospital a number of times.
But Jesse knew it.
He'd talk with him, knew his nickname, where he lived.
His habit was getting out in the backyard, shoot that pistol up in the air till it was empty, and then go back in the house.
He did this every week.
And Jesse was.
But when Jesse was killed, there wasn't any big set society, the department, the individual going to the department was upset about it.
Why the difference between the two incidents?
Why the difference in the reaction?
One was a deliberate, planned incident.
The other was an unavoidable accident.
Early on in your career, you work in Youth Division 1.
What did this job involve?
In Texas, children under the age of 10 are not deemed capable of making a legal decision.
Juveniles from the age of 10 to 17
are and can be held responsible for their actions.
Any offense that they commit either against themselves or against society was handled by the youth police.
We also handled
Registration of bicycles.
Licensing bicycles at that time were not anymore.
Runaways.
This type of service.
Thanks.
Well, I guess now I'm going to get asked, what was the most common thing?
It handled a diversity.
In the youth division?
Shoplifting, theft, and runaways.
What age, or what's the most common age for, you know, describe a typical problem you face?
It's hard to describe typical.
Eleven-year-old white boy pimping two girls.
One eleven, one twelve.
Is he typical?
Or the boy that gets a bad report about the first six weeks of school, don't want to go home, so he's turned into a runaway.
The kid that got a bicycle for Christmas, he can't get out riding it without a registration or a license tag on it, because he don't know the difference.
This one's typical.
A girl that goes to the store and shoplifts a tube of lipstick, because she don't have one that color.
How would you say the kids today compare to the kids that you work with then?
Think they're pretty much the same?
I think the drug influence has made a lot of change.
I don't know what happened in that field.
I can't say, but I'm afraid that it has.
Like what?
more than taking drugs, experimenting with drugs, committing offenses to get money to buy drugs, being on drugs and under the effect of them.
The main thing we had then that could be considered drugs would be alcohol or hallucinations.
if it's kept up will kill you.
Alcohol, if it's kept up for an extreme will kill you.
But not to the extent that drugs are used now.
Okay.
Ah, here's the one we were talking about earlier.
In 1966, the Supreme Court ruled in the Randy case that a suspect has to be informed of their rights when they're arrested.
About the same time, they ruled in the Mapp case that you can't have legal search warrant that specifies what you're after.
How do these rulings affect your work?

of the effect if you are a patrol officer and you are patrolling out here on the midnight shift and you see a car go by with two people sitting in it the back end nearly dragging the ground driving down the street obeying every traffic law you can think of
Why would you want to stop that car?
Because that son of a bitch carried something stolen in the back end of that thing.
Otherwise, he wouldn't be dragging the bottom like that.
How are you going to justify searching the back end of that car to see what he stole?
Yes, it affects your work.
You've got to find him in some kind of a violation.

strong enough where you can put him in jail over a lieutenant's objection to give you the right to search that car under the guise of being inventorying the property of the car before you put it in the PD panel.
Yeah.
Do you think...
Take your average policeman or you.

Do you think that things like the Miranda warning and the restrictions on searches, do you think those are good in the fact that they may protect an individual or bad in the fact that they may hinder enforcement?
They hinder enforcement.
I don't agree with the theory that society should be burdened with the expense of furnishing a high-priced lawyer to somebody that has been charged with committing an offense.
I don't think that's society's burden.
I don't necessarily agree with the idea that he should be told everything that he says can and may be used against him.
By law, he should be a grown man and he should be held accountable for his actions, period.
I don't agree with the requirement for a warrant.

If you had stolen a pencil from the library by accident, just put it in your pocket without even thinking that it might be yours or it might be somebody else's left laying on the table there, and a police officer stops you at the door and starts with all this warning, what are you going to tell them?
He ain't going to listen to nothing until he gets you to jail.
The jail lieutenant tells you the same thing again.
And the jail lieutenant ain't going to say nothing until he gets the corporation court judge down there and he gives you the warning again.
By that time, you're a little bit pissed off about that damn pencil.
And then the next day, when the detective gets you out to ask you about what
caused the offense to you being in the jail, and he gives you the warning and writes it down again on what time you were given the warning by who, are you going to be eager to tell him?
I don't think so.
Yeah, it hinders law or justice.
How does a hindrance balance out with any possible benefit?
Can you name me one benefit?
What's stated a lot is it protects the individual from...
Anything you say can and may be used against you.
If you are unable to obtain an attorney of your choice, an attorney will be furnished.
I don't agree with any one of those.
What about the search restrictions?
That's a different one altogether.
The Constitution of the United States
comes along there under one of the laws or one of the amendments, that you shall be secure in your person against all unreasonable searches or seizures.
The word that brings into question is unreasonable.
If it's a reasonable search or a reasonable seizure, I believe it should be ineffective.

Just like I pointed out a while ago, if you've got a car going down the street at 2.30 in the morning, two old boys sitting in the front end of it, and the back end of it dragging the ground, I believe you've got cause for reasonable search for that vehicle.
But as things stand today, no court in the land would oppose it.
Reasonable seems to be pretty subjective.
It is.
How can you establish something that could be consistent?
I'm not a lawyer.
I can't.
All I can tell you is what's reasonable in my way of thinking and why I think that.
And if by virtue of being a policeman on the beat for 12 years, 5 years, or 20 years, you have a reasonable cause to believe
that a stolen TV is in the back end of that car.
Or that a motor from another car is stuck in the back end of that.
That should be grabbed for stopping and searching.
You're not accusing the people of anything until you find something that is out of line.
And then I believe it becomes incumbent on them
to prove that they're not.
When did the Fort Worth Police Department start making you read Miranda and restricting your activities and searches?
I couldn't even say I don't even know.
Well, the court started in 66.
I'm just curious how long it took to put it.
You came to work one day and they said, all right, this is what we're going to do.
Oh, no.
It would be a gradual buildup and an overreaction to whatever the actual decision was.
It always is.
They overreact to it in such a way as to protect themselves.
Then as the decision comes out and becomes more understood, more widely read, then adjustments are made to ease the restrictions that you've been placed under.
Okay.
Let's see.
We may have already discussed this.
We'll try again.
The rights of the accused are very strong in the U.S. Miranda, right to counsel, tendency of judges to throw out cases on technicalities.
How much more difficult do these make police work?
It makes the police work a lot more difficult.
It increases the paperwork.
No, I didn't say how much.
And it reduces the amount of police work because so much time has to be spent on paperwork justifying what you did.
Or explaining that you went right down the line at 8.05, at 8.06, at 8.08.
So will my fish.
Can you give an example?
Yeah, any examples?
I mean, out of your own experience or just thinking of it?
Either good or bad, of increased awareness for the individual and the responsibility of the police to recognize and respect, at least in the court's opinion,
Yeah, that was a bad question.
Any example, can you give any examples from your own experience of the effects of these, either good or bad effects of other, you've already given some, so this is kind of a repetitious question.
Well,
When I was assigned to the Texas office burglary section, well before any of this had come into being, at that time we had approximately
a 25% clearance rate of all burglaries that were reported, with about a 19% recovery of all burglary losses.
I'm not thoroughly familiar with what the percentages would be now.
I doubt they would be anywhere near there.
And I believe it's almost strictly attributable to the fact that so much more extensive paperwork is required that less cases can be worked by the detective.
He has less time.
If one case takes him two or three days paperwork, and he's getting five or six cases assigned to him a day, something's gotta slide.
What was the perception of the policeman of the flower children?
I don't know if you want to distinguish between flower children and hippies or whether you get all the same.
Were they a minor problem or was it...
Try to think back now.
We didn't have any...
First, we had our black minority groups.
And while they were gone, we had what we more or less called the flower children.
They were groups.
And then later on came what would be termed hippies.
There were more or less several years in between.
The Flower Children, they formed groups.
